commentBody:
Before anything else:  This is not Gary Larson the cartoonist.

Now that that's out of the way, back to our regularly scheduled programming.

sam,

i really enjoyed your writeup this evening.  it improved my mood considerably.

thanks.

"Said one 45-degree angle to another, 'You're so acute!'"
"Must be a complimentary angle."

(These puns are never obtuse.)
Got scared.  Almost worried that this would end the streak.

A very fun breezy puzzle, 'punny'!  I loved it.  (I think the Monday and Tuesday got switched.)

Thanks for the amusement!
Fun puzzle. Perfect for Tuesday and easier than Monday this week.
Funny people calling this easier than yesterday. 4 minutes yesterday, 9 minutes today. Really struggled in the SE, thought I might get skunked today actually
Fun to see my town as a Crossword answer. Home of the Rainiers! Grit City.
Also felt harder than a typical Tuesday to me. Not that I’m complaining!

ASCENTOFMAN made me smile. 

Last to fill: the I in PAIGExMIR. I knew neither, but it seemed to be the only letter that would work, and it was right.

Had blooperS before GAGREELS (at least until I realized Mars and Mercury aren't bODS ... though they do have god-bods I guess) and REr_n (space left blank because ran and run both fit) before REAIR. Also mistyped MADAT as kADAT and spent a bit trying to figure out a "sewer lines?" answer that fit S_AKS.

Yesterday felt hard for a Monday, today felt Tuesdayish but slow (slower than my average even). Hmm.
I finished this about 10% faster than normal. Pretty normal Tuesday solve time. I think this one had a little more chew than Monday's solve.

What a treat!  An excellent puzzle and a chance to tell a Satchel Paige legend.  This is how I heard it.  No telling how many re-tellings this has gone through.

Satchel Paige was a stellar pitcher in the Negro Leagues.  He was also a wonderful story teller, and this story is part of his legacy.

He claimed to have a lightning fast pick off move, a move in baseball where the pitcher throws to first base trying to pick off a runner taking a lead off first base  This was instead of pitching to the batter.

He claimed he had a man of first, and a 2-2 count on the batter. 

He said he made a casual move, and the batter easily scampered back.  Then he did a better pickoff move, and it was close but the runner was clearly back on base in time.

The third time he used one of better pickoff moves, and it was an incredibly close play at first, with the runner diving head first back to the base.  The umpire called him safe.

"Next", Paige said, "I made my best, sneakiest pickoff throw".

"What happened?", someone asked.

"I struck the batter out, " says Satchel.

The clue that hung me up for a while here was SYNOD, as I have not heard of a SYNOD and also I haven't heard of that use of the word YEN, NAGS or RAGS seemed to fit equally, and I didn't know enough about crank cases to get OILPAN without all the other cross clues first.

The corner with TETLEY also took a while because I'd never heard of TETLEY and a few of the cross clues a few different things could have fit the space.

Overall a medium gimmick and a tough puzzle for a Tuesday.

🧵I have been admonished that this is NOT the right forum to complain about & seek to change the NYTG stats displays.

Fair enough, I agree to all that.

But ’fore I go, I’d like to add one last little degradation that people should be aware of:

I’ve completed over 4,000 NYTG crosswords, some using AutoCheck, many using Wikipedia.  Always learned something interesting.

ONE THING I won’t be able to know is how many puzzles I’ve completed, because the counter now reads “4,0..,” AND THAT’S IT.  I have to make do with only the hundreds & the thousands place, 😒‼️
A really fun theme that made me smile. I caught onto A CUTE ANGLE quickly, which helped with the others, and led to a personal best. I’m tickled to find it entertaining as well as a smooth solve.
The OREO strikes again!
Really well balanced with clever clueing and a smooth solve.  Easy for a Tuesday.

Another Tuesday that seemed chewier than usual, which is AOK by me. I saw ACORN… before reading the clue and was looking for “Too tight shoes?” —ACORNSQUASH. I would love to see SPACEBAR clued as “Mos Eisley Cantina on Tatooine?” Finally, not knocking Pulko’s motorcycling feat but what’s the big deal about “solo”? It’s not like Charles Lindbergh flying the Atlantic where you can’t sleep (I assume) or mountain climbing where your team actually helps and protects you. Honestly it seems like it would be harder logging all those miles with someone on your back or in a sidecar. Or am I missing something? Motorcycle marathoners of the world please chime in.

Very enjoyable

Lots of great words IMPETUS, ARDENT, USURPS

The STUB / STUD symmetry was a nice touch

Went through the labyrinth adroitly?
AMAZING GRACE

Fun one. Got a Taco Tuesday clue in there, too. 

If there are those who say this was easier than yesterday I'm with them, but don't feel strongly about it.  A SCENT OF MAN, that was gold.

Serious question to the NYT:
Does ETSY pay you to have their store mentioned every other week in the crossword?
So tiresome, clumsy and obvious.
I’d never heard of ETSY until I started doing these which I guess is the point.

Here’s my life:

“Daddy, can you give me another piggyback ride” 

(SYNOD)

“Of course. Climb on!”

That was delightful! Done in half my average time. I particularly liked 45D [Sewer lines?]. Quite clever.

I think the emus need to eat some Oreos though!

My Diary of a Crossword Fiend review of today's puzzle: https://crosswordfiend.com/2025/08/04/tuesday-august-5-2025/#ny As always, Diary of a Crossword Fiend covers several puzzles each day — some from major newspapers and some more indie. Come by, rate a puzzle or two, and learn about some good puzzles you might otherwise miss.
Absolutely lovely.

The top half of the puzzle was quick and easy, but the bottom half not so much.  It was more fun than  the top half because it seemed more complex, but that always varies with the solver.

ACUTE ANGLE and ASCENT OF MAN were finished with the crosses before I read the clues, and when I did?  Really funny.  Genius!

Thanks Gary and Amy.  Got any more?
Very fun and very tight. Clever theme. No foreign languages, sports, or college abbreviations, very few proper nouns, and no “words” that are a bit of a stretch that I recall. Super impressive!!!
10:32 no help. It’s been awhile
Mica is a mineral, not a rock.
Of course I have to wonder: is the co-creator of this puzzle*that* Gary Larson?

OILPAN made me think of my first car, an '82 Honda Civic. My brother taught me how to change the oil myself. It was easy because I could raise the hood, lean in and put my hand on the oil filter. Those were simpler days....not saying better or worse, just simpler.

(BTW, it was a stick shift with a TACH.)

Nice puzzle, and perhaps skewed a little toward older solvers.

It was nice to see ARLO and Janice mentioned, as the strip just celebrated its 40th anniversary. And I was just starting college in southern Iowa when Satchel PAIGE made his 3-inning, 1 hit, pitching appearance for the Kansas City Athletics at age 59, part of the effort to make Satchel eligible for a MLB pension.

Thanks, Gary and Amy!

Punny theme that did not elicit a groan from me? A rare thing indeed 😀

I liked this puzzle. I solved it in typical Tuesday time, and it offered just the right amount of resistance - it was mostly easy, but there were several pleasantly challenging spots. Personally I perceived the grid as perfect Tuesday difficulty.

FALCON reminded me of the theme song from the Polish tv series "Pan Wołodyjowski" ("Sir Wołodyjowski"). The series was a 1960s adaptation of Henryk Sienkiewicz's historical literary epic of the same title. The protagonist, Jerzy Michał Wołodyjowski, portrayed by beloved actor Tadeusz Łomnicki, was a master Polish swordsman, an officer in the Polish army in the middle of the 17th century. For his stature he was called the Little Knight. There is war, love, betrayal, and honor, and the setting is the Ukrainian steppe (at the time, the lands of modern Ukraine were within Polish borders). The theme song, a beautiful ballad composed by the famous Wojciech Kilar, and sung by the actor Leszek Herdegen, describes the steppe as so big even a falcon can't see it all from up high: "W stepie szerokim/którego okiem/nawet sokolim nie zmierzysz/stań, unieś głowę/wsłuchaj się w słowa/pieśni o małym rycerzu" (In the wide steppe/which even with an falcon's eye/you cannot measure/raise your head/listen to the words/of the song of the little knight."

PS. In early September we're getting a puppy: a gray standard poodle ❤️
Just excellent.
What a delightful puzzle!
Loved this one.
Very easy for a Tuesday. Breezy. So was word splits the theme? Where are the constructor notes? Second day in a row, no constructor notes. What gives?

I really enjoyed this one. Nice to have the wordplay, even though it wasn't too difficult. 
The ARIE/GAG corner was tricky for me, there are so many singers I don't know. The taco and Satchel clues would have been impossible but crossers did it. 
I found it easier than yesterday.
I’ve always wondered:  does Oreo pay for its frequent appearance in the NYT crossword?  Just curious.

Fun puzzle. Theme was in vicinity of dad jokes so right up my alley (oops). And.. speaking of dad jokes, an amazing puzzle find today. A Sunday from June 17, 1990 by Jack L. Steinhardt with the title "Searching questions." Some clues and answers: "WHERE'S THE STATION?" RIGHTOFWAY "WHERE'S THE SECOND?" BEFOREHAND "WHERE'S THE FINDING?" AFTERTHEFACT "WHERE'S GREENWICH?" AHEADOFTIME "WHERE'S THE PITCH?" PASTPERFECT "WHERE'S THE WAVE?" AFTERSHOCK And there were more. Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=6/17/1990&g=38&d=D I'll shut up now. ...

Now that was a more Tuesday puzzle. Doable but required a little thought in places; the usual suspects of sports stars etc.
The theme was ACUTE one.

Still battling Alpaca fleece. The fibres do not want to let the grime go. Is it worth it for the hope of a pair of socks? Probably.

Not sure why but one of my favorite words is SYNOD: A synod (/ˈsɪnəd/) is a council of a Christian denomination, usually convened to decide an issue of doctrine, administration or application. The word synod comes from the Ancient Greek σύνοδος (synodos) 'assembly, meeting'; the term is analogous with the Latin word concilium 'council'. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Synod Loved ASCENTOFMAN and perhaps a generational split between the examples? (Axe=teens, Old Spice=old dudes?). It's interesting that the deodorant Axe' was launched in 1983 but it took until 2015 to show up as an Xword answer, [Grooming brand for "helping guys get the girl]. A lot of talk today about OREO and ETSY but AXE is a contender with 459 appearances. Favorite clue? [Oviform : egg :: dolabriform : ___]

Little did I know that when this first aired, some 37 years ago, I would find myself in said situation, in reality: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=X7fxjN_FFX0 (Well, not in reality, as I "married into" my co-op.) A note on the hyphen, etc.--I, and the New Yorker, are big fans of the dieresis--without it, "cooperation" means "the act or study of becoming a barrel-maker." A--cute theme--"a cute angle" reminds me of a line from one of my favorite indie films, Patricia Rozema's *I've Heard the Mermaids Singing*. But IRL no one says "acron shells," unless they've been hiking barefoot in an oak forest.
Serious question:  Does the American Orthopaedic Society pay the Times to have ULNA appear in so many crosswords?

A little post-solve wikipedia has taught me that Axe® is marketed in the UK as Lynx®, and, until 2002, elsewhere (South Africa, for one) as EGO®. It also introduced me to the term "smellmaxxing." SMELLMAXXING--now wouldn't that be a wonderful late-week entry!

Oreo. Amos. I’m buying this round.
The cookie jokes walk right into the bar themselves today.



Do the gods pay for all the free publicity in the NYTXW?

I really didn't want GAG for GAG REELS.  A GAG is intentional, and aren't those outtakes inadvertent errors/events/goofs?

I had SPACE KEY....duh.
STUB and then STUD...that was fun.  It created in me a desire for the other two corner entries to be a similar fun pair.  Maybe BUST and DUST?  Sigh.

Nice to have some grown-up vocab today!  STASIS, USURP,, IMPETUS!  
(Curious way to clue ULNA, BTW.)

Happy Tuesday, everyone.

Fun puzzle, but as a noun "Snoot" most often refers to a person's (or dog's) nose. Thought the theme was going to be mathematical after 17 across. Happy to see some baseball love for a non-Yankee player.

Seeds in alone in funding this hard.

Too many references I didn't know, from baseball and space stations crossing, so synod being a new word, didn't think of oil pan and had nothing to solve it with.

Also need to look up alit, and sewer lines being seams.

Just posting for anyone who didn't find it easy, to break the sea of comments from people who know who Satchel Paige is, have heard of mica, etc.
From SYNOD to SNOOT, this was a hoot.

Is it me or am I missing something. I am still a bit clueless as to a theme for today. I happy to have solved faster than my average. I’ve read the article and parsed it all out but still am in the dark. I will share that my day is never complete until the NYT crossword is solved wether I get the theme or not.

"Sew! It seams!"
                         -Buffalo Bill




I wonder if this is the same Gary Larson who did "Doonesbury".

Route out? AWAY FROM HOME

Government medal?  AWARD OF THE STATE

Urban flight? ALOFT IN THE CITY


Nice puzzle to come home to. My mom is now 96, but quite frail.
Had a pack of Selena Gomez (cinnamon creme) Oreos as a road snack. And the local paper up there had a special edition of puzzles from USA Today, which reminded me of the NYTX with emus, Alda, SSN, ekes, yens, bicep, acai, etc.

Did I miss anything? Barry was AWOL?
Great puzzle. Nothing else to add.

Maybe the puzzle was AHEAD OF lettuce - peeling off layers to reveal its core 🤷🏼‍♀️  That’s the best play on words I could come up with after getting back home from the east coast late last night. NO LIE, I was delirious last night after days on end of too little sleep. There’s no place like home 🏠😍 Thank you, Gary (not the Far Side 🤣) Larson and Amy Ensz for a fun grid today. 

Happy Tuesday everyone!

What a great puzzle. Lots of fun, and the theme entries were the icing on the cake. Only one lookup. I had to change some guesses, but so be it. (My first thought for the far-sighted bird was Eagle, which of course didn't fit.  Ahem.)

Congrats to the constructors. More from them, please!

Learned a new word today: SYNOD

Slightly more difficult than a normal Tuesday but appreciated the challenge today.
Taco Tuesday...me gusta! Muchas gracias G y A!!
A little too reliant on trivia and other obscure words for my taste, but otherwise a fine puzzle.
Never mind the OREOs, how does the Chicago TRIBune weasel their way in here? Aren't they competitors? TIME magazine not so much; they don't even have a crossword puzzle.

TEATRE_/T_TLEY obviously needed an E to finish the puzzle, even though I had never heard of that coffee brand. Oh! It never occurred to me that "a cuppa" might be tea! Not that I've ever heard of that tea brand either.

Next I'm going to find out what kind of "essential oil" a tea tree could provide.

“An urge to come to wordplay and make provocative comments about plurals, usage, days of the week, cookies, and pretty much anything”

A GREED TO DISAGREE
Spent a few moments wondering what an ACORN SHELL would do to my remaining teeth LOL!

This one sas smooth except for. natick for me on ARLO and TRIB, 
also unfortunately SYNOD, YEN, or OILPAN were not in my vocab  which made fof a tough cross
Fun puzzle! A little more thinking involved than a typical Tuesday, which I appreciated!

So, since I first visited Wordplay this morning, there has been posted a "preview" (beta version?) for the new format for displaying comments, at least on a PC. It appears that still only three replies will appear, without opening a further link. However, it also appears that replies-to-replies don't appear automatically, but as a drop down from said reply--in other words, a branching tree of responses. A bit weird, when one might be "replying" to the last post, but are really addressing the the thread as a whole. (Does this make sense?) 

Gives me a bit of a headache, but that might be just the Great Canadian Smaze:-(

I have nothing relevant to say about the puzzle, but I do need to tell you and hope that you can pass it on to Deb, as well, that both your writing and hers, brings me joy. I always get an out loud laugh or two from the Wordplay column. Not only that, but I apparently have the same type of sense of humor as you, and it always makes me feel included in your community. Thanks for that and giving me chuckles at a time when there's not a lot to chuckle about these days.

Late answer find with a VERY surprising result. Sort of stumbled across this with a Xword Info search based on partial letters. Anyway, a word I wasn't familiar with...

INEE 

Seems like a very useful piece and and... it had 148 appearances in pre-Shortz puzzles, always clued as: 
"Arrow Poison" (or slight variations)

But... it NEVER appeared in a Shortz era puzzle. I can't remember ever encountering that before. Can't help but wonder if there are some other relatively simple examples of short fill that might have undergone that change. Might do some searches, that but could be complicated. 

...
Is Monday's puzzle showing as not complete for anyone else? It's interrupting a streak. Is it a glitch that will get resolved?

In addition to TETLEY, also found in this puzzle [TEA]TREE, S[TEA]MROOM, and  ACU[TEA]NGLE.

I wonder if this puzzle may have grown out of a grid with a different theme originally
LOL, I had A COOKS HELL for a long time… instead of A CORN SHELL
Anyone know what's happening with the Midis? Are they only coming out on Mondays now?

Back when I was into baseball, Cecil COOPer was my favorite.  Even though he's not clued as such in here, it's fun to see him crossing the amazing Satchel PAIGE! And, so near to CREW, for my old team, the Brew CREW!! Cooooooooooop!!!!

I spent a good many days up in my tree house in the backyard or lounging in the backyard  with my little radio listening to the Brewers games. I later upgraded to a boombox because I was definitely not a girl AHEADOFherTIME. 

Nowadays, I suppose I would be up in the treehouse with a crossword puzzle. And when i lounge out in the sun (which we call butterballing), I am covered with SPF as high as it goes instead of the baby oil I used back in the day!! ☀️ Yeesh!!! 

Anyhow, fun and fast one for me, but not so fast that I didn't appreciate the theme while filling it out. That's just about that pace I like things at. So did I think it was A CUTE puzzle? Yes, I did! NO LIE!! 

But also, why does the New York Times keep trying to push eels on us!? How much is Big Eel paying to constantly have them in the puzzle!? Today it was subliminal, but you can bet your bottom dollar it was there! I demand to see the manager!!

By the way, I just had to get a new license and normally I look like a seriously deranged party girl from the '80s in them, so this time I tried to tone it down my big goofy smile and poofy hair and now I look like a person demanding to see the manager... Or like an old man trying to return soup at a deli. 🐳🌊

Gary Larson and Amy Ensz made a great puzzle. So far one of my favorites for wordplay. I loved all of it. I especially liked 45D. I laughed out loud when I solved it. All of them were wonderful. It was an easy play and didn't take very long, but it felt a little challenging.  I really had to think about it and use a few crosses to get to the puns. Making me work a bit for them increased my enjoyment of that dopamine moment. I solved each one  with glee. Thank you for a really good time. Looking forward to more from you folks. ✌️

Speaking of comic strips, "Get Fuzzy"(by Darby Conley not Gary Larson) featured Satchel Pooch and Bucky Katt, who were named after Satchel Paige and Buck O'Neil.

They both played professional baseball before joining the MLB. Buck became the first Black coach in the MLB.
I had LASE instead of TASE for a while - took me a min to figure that one out!  Fun puzzle!
Meh, decent enough puzzle but not a fan of some of the clues and solutions. But hey, I can overlook OOH and NOLIE for a Satchel Paige clue and SYNOD.
Can’t wait for a puzzle where the theme is yoko ono sitting by lake erie eating oreos while listening to etta sing an aria accompanied by eno…
I know this isn't a huge streak by some of the aces here, but just hit my first 30 day streak.  Got through four consecutive Fridays and Saturdays.  Yay me!!
Any puzzle with Bette Midler in it is okay by me.  Clever theme. Thanks for the fun.
Got stuck at the end on ASCENTOFMeN instead of  ASCENTOFMaN. Whoops. We made it though. A good Tuesday for sure. We loved STUB and STUD in the north corners.

Steve,

So Amy Ensz is the cartoonist?

@Barry Ancona

It's about time you showed up.

@Barry Ancona

We missed you. Francis was actually worried. Good to see you back.

@Andrzej
Seconded

@Steve L

You know how Andrzej exaggerates.  

I was simply hoping that there would be a resumption of the  solace we all get from the routine of the forum.

Or something.

@Barry Ancona

Just popped in to see if you were here.
Very glad that you are.

I’ll go back into hiding now.

@Andrzej

Don't believe him, Barry.  

I wasn't worried, I was just...I just thought...oh hell, I was worried.

Everybody happy now?

@Francis,

Kind of feels like … I dunno … maybe there’s some of the LWORD here today …
@Francis🥹🥹🥹 I was worried too.

@Francis
BA did this at least once before, prompting some somber speculation. I wish he would do like Lewis and announce when he will be away for awhile .

@Hardroch
Or at least present a doctor's excuse!

@Barry Ancona
Comforting to know you are back!

@Mike You're probably right. 

What do a pair of angles get when they stay out in the sun? A co-tan!

@Mike

Wanna a five letter word for making three puns?  Try angle.

@Mike

Your power to pun appears to be infinite. Sometime you should tell us your origin story.
@Mike I came here for sensible people, and i saw sillies!

@Mike
Why must you always stir up a rhombus?
@Eric Hougland, Loved hearing this. I had not heard of Neko Case before, what a lovely voice. Here’s another: https://youtu.be/9AXVBtBJjLw?si=8uZAXa_S6WbgdUV1

@NYC Traveler

Neko Case has been at the top of our list for about 20 years now. In addition to being a fantastic singer, she writes some very quirky lyrics.

@Francis

Don't know if you saw my reply to you on yesterday's comment about the Negro Leagues. The Negro Leagues Baseball Museum and the American Jazz Museum share a building at 18th & Vine in Kansas City, MO. nlbm.com is their website.

@Francis

Used to live on the Kansas side, and a daughter and some other relatives still live in the metro area. Big barbecue town, and other places to hit include the Nelson Art Gallery and the nearby Kauffman memorial garden, the Steamboat Arabia museum, the Liberty Memorial and WWI museum, Crown Center, the Plaza, and lots of parks and fountains.

@JayTee

I've made barbecue a top priority both times I've been to Kansas City as an adult.

@Francis
Thank you for your explanation - though I have to say it was still like a foreign language! No matter, I was glad to hear the story, after assuming the clue referenced a  'satchel' maker from a place called Cooperstown, so famous everyone knows about it. Like the famous biscuits, which I looked up, would never have guessed!

@Francis
I can't resist adding my own favorite story about Satchel Paige and a young Willie Mays.
Willie Mays describing when, as a 17-year-old, faced Satchel Paige for the first time:
"It was 1948. Satchel had a very, very good fastball. But he threw me a little breaking ball, just to see what I could do, and I hit it off the top of the fence. And I got a double. When I got to second, Satchel told the third baseman, 'Let me know when that little boy comes back up.'
Three innings later, I go to kneel down in the on-deck circle, and I hear the third baseman say, 'There he is.' Satch looked at the third baseman, and then he looked at me.
I walk halfway to home plate and he says, 'Little boy.' I say, 'Yes, sir?' because Satch was much older than I am, so I was trying to show respect.
He walked halfway to home plate and said, 'Little boy, I'm not going to trick you. I'm going to throw you three fastballs and you're going to go sit down' and I'm saying in my mind, 'I don't think so.' If he threw me three of the same pitch, I'm going to hit it somewhere.
He threw me two fastballs and I just swung...I swung right through it. And the third ball he threw, and I tell people this all the time, he threw the ball and then he started walking. And he says, 'Go sit down.' 
This is while the ball was in the air.
He was just a magnificent pitcher."
~Willie Mays Comes Home
GQ Magazine interview 2010

@JayTee
Calvin Trillin’s “American Fried” is a mouthwatering testament to Kansas City cuisine.  One of the best food books ever, along with his “Alice, Let’s Eat “ and “Third Helpings.”
@JayTee Thanks so much for the trip down memory lane! I used to visit my grandpa in KC
@Chris I came here to write the exact same thing as your first paragraph. Glad I’m not the only one!
@Chris synod is one of those cool/fun church words like nave and narthax... useful in crosswords but kind of niche otherwise!

@David Pearce

Yikes, that really is inexcusable, especially if they were capable of providing all digits when it was greater than 3000 but less than 4000.

@David Pearce

Give more specifics.  On my iPhone app, it clearly tells me I've solved 4,771 puzzles in the new "Me" stats tab.

On my desktop, my stats online show the same 4,771 puzzles.

Where is it you're not seeing past the hundreds place?

(Note:  I've solved far more than 4,771 puzzles.  Just not through the NYT interfaces.)

@David Pearce

I concur with Steve L. On the iOS app, I see my 3834 completions, my completion rate, and my current and longest streaks in all their full amounts; and the same on the website.

I like the stats breakdown on the web a lot more than on the phone, as you can at once see the best, average, and current times for each day of the week individually, while on the phone app you can only see one at a time for all days at once.

The phone app also does not show the past seven days of actual solve times like the website, only the ones for the current calendar week.
@David Pearce Is it possible you set the font size larger than the default size on your device? That may cause any text (including numeric strings) to get truncated.

@JayTee   My "completion rate" doesn't make sense.  Of the puzzles I have started, I have completed all but one.  My completion rate should be upwards of 99.5%, but that's not what these new stats say.   Who do I ask about this?
@Steve L I don't see any stats on how many puzzles I've solved.

@Francis 

🧵Thanks! Under the “ancien régime,”you saw the entire number of puzzles you’d completed, whether 1️⃣, or 1️⃣,0️⃣0️⃣0️⃣.

Now, MAYBE if you have completed LESS THAN 1,000 puzzles, that full number might fit in the allotted place.

BUT LOOK AROUND YOU: Even things we once trusted are getting worse.  As a whole society, we’re getting more stupid and less able to THINK WELL.

@Ms. Billie M. Spaight

On the app, look for the Me tab at the bottom of the screen.

Online, statistics are found just to the right of the crossword icon on the main puzzle page.

Hope that helps!

@Steve L

Or in the hamburger drop-down menu under the "The Crossword" submenu, along with the Archives, Bonus Puzzles, and How to Solve…
@SP I don’t know, 111,800 miles seems like an awfully long way to travel by oneself.

@Dave S

Sometimes I long for that.

@SP
Second time trying to point out that your clue, “Too tight shoes”, would have been an equally good one for the actual answer, but won’t bother to explain because the emus evidently didn’t like the four-letter word I used the first time.

@SP

If everything goes well, solo is okay.  2000 days and 112k miles though ... there must have been some rough spots.  That she made it across all seven continents managing the riding, navigation, and human interactions alone is a pretty big deal.

@SP
I would venture to say your clue would have been apt for the answer:  A CORN’S HELL.

@SP,

FWIW, I like your clues better!

@SP
I've never heard of her or that journey either. All I know is that is one monumental accomplishment. Me along with a couple of my fellow Harley riders had once decided to embark on an Iron Butt trip. That's 1000 miles within a 24 hour timeframe. Even after calculating the speeds and distances to safely accomplish that, it turned out to be much more challenging then first expected. Simple right? 500 miles out, 500 miles back. Yeah, right.

@Gareth

The reason you see ETSY, OREO, ARIA, ONO, ENO, ETTA and other words on repeat is because they enable other answers because of the letter patterns or vowels they contain. There are times when the answers that constructor needs/wants to include can only appear by including crosses with some of these "helper" words.

The style of crosswords that appear in most US publications contains many answers that have to interlock, so a constructor must use actual names, words, or phrases.

ETSY has been used 10 times this year, twice in two months. It's been used 103 times since 2014, so its use this year is only slightly higher than usual.

@Gareth

I must finally come clean. I can no longer live with the secret.

I am not who you thought I was.

In fact, I'm am the consigliere for the vowel mafia. For years I've been accepting kickbacks for getting our words into puzzles all over the US. Now that I've told you this my days are numbered, so you can expect to soon never see The likes of ETSY and ERE in a grid ever again.

Ciao. It's been fun.

I remember those days.  Even for a non-DIY guy like me, it was satisfying to be able to change oil and oil filter.

@Andrzej

Sure, that's what I do now. But back then I had my first real job and wasn't earning much, so I could save a few $ by doing it myself. And I got a certain amount of satisfaction from being ABLE to do it as a girl (way back then, working on cars was still perceived as mostly a guy thing.)

For a while I had 4 snow tires and changed them myself twice a year.  Got pretty good at it. Now if I get a flat, I call roadside assistance. 

But when I said things were simpler, I guess I really meant that car engines were simpler. Not necessarily better, but definitely simpler.

@CRTH et al.
Back in college, in the 80's, I changed the oil in my (inherited) Buick Regal--once, just to prove I could do it. The problem wasn't changing the oil, it was disposing the old oil.

@CRTH
I still do basic stuff like oil, tires, brakes, suspension on cars, boats, atv's, etc.  My neighborhood is full of 30 somethings who have a service for grass cutting, house cleaning, fertilizing, etc. I can only imagine what they are thinking about that guy banging around in his garage.

@CRTH I loved working on my cars back in the day. I would tear down the engine on my old 67 Alfa and put it back together just for fun. Then there was the time when a defective timing belt snapped while I was driving. I glided to the side of the road, got my toolbox from the trunk. Popped off the head, walked to a machine shop and had him straighten a couple of slightly bent valves. Back to the car with a new head gasket and belt and was back on the road. Total time less than two hours at a cost of about $30. Maybe $150 today, but of course any kind of do-it-yourself repair like that would be impossible with today’s cars. I still do oil changes on a car once it’s past its initial 3 years. Imfind it cheaper and faster than having it done.

@Al  in Pittsburgh

I once tried to summerize Polish history in the 1500 character limit of these posts, but I gave up 🤣. Essentially, out earliest recorded history starts in the mid-10th century CE. Two strong rulers put Poland on the map, but then several centuries of decline followed. The kingdom regained power in the early 14th century, and by the end of the century Poland united with Lithuania when the Lithuanian Grand Prince married the daughter of the last king of the Polish Piast dynasty, and his heir. Wars with the Teutonic knights doninated the 15th century. Poland grew in power, especially in the 16rh century, a time of great prosperity. Disastrous wars in the 17th century - with Sweden, Ukrainian Cossacks, Turkey - ruined the kingdom (it was called a Republic by then, but there still was a king). While absolutism developed elsewhere in Europe, the Polish kings were weakened by the growing power of regional magnates. The country was so weak by the end of the 18th century that Austria, Prussia and Russia divided it between themselves, almost without a fight. Poland reemerged in 1918 (with Wilson's support), but after 7 years of democracy degenerated into dictatorship, and was swiftly defeated by Germany in 1939. Abandonned by Western allies, it fell into the Soviet sphere of influence in 1945, regained democracy in 1989, only to let populists ruin it all over again in 2015. A brief resurgence of reason will likely end in 2027, with more populist rule.

@Lisa it’s not the type of thing which the NYT would ever admit to….But one can guarantee that they are approached by advertisers who want product placement in the puzzle.

Its first appearance coincided with the start of the Shortz era. Until then, it was exclusively clued as the Greek prefix for mountain."

@Paul

@Lisa Well Asta seems to have been put in the dog house.

@JD

@SP there are lots of faulty assumptions in your conclusion.

Whether or not a puzzle needs to be specifically constructed for a product isn’t the issue. 

A puzzle solution doesn’t even need to get modified to make money….

Here are 2 easy ways to involve advertisers in the puzzle…

1)modify clues so that they reference in answer in a way the sponsor prefers.  Such as using the advertising slogan instead of “black and white cookie”

2) Use a product such as Oreo in a puzzle more often….or on specific dates when Nabisco has an advertising campaign going.  The NYT can know months in advance when it’s going to run a puzzle…more than enough time to talk with advertisers and ensure advertising dollars.


They don’t need to involve the constructors at all…Just ad sales and the editor which lets the advertisers know what date their chosen puzzle will run.

@SP Ignoring all of the times Nabisco comes up in the clues…Take a look at July 26 2019 in the archives…There are TWO clues which point to product placement.

1) it comes from Mars…where the answer is Twix 

2)Oreo___ where the answer is Thins.


This is just one example of many where there are obvious links to brands and their products.   Accidents don’t happen.   The editors are very aware that products are being mentioned.   And one has to assume that awareness leads to revenue.

And frankly I don’t have a problem with the NYT squeezing every penny it can from the puzzle as long as it doesn’t sacrifice the quality of the puzzle.  And I think that it’s naive to think that they don’t do that.

@Paul what you are pointing out is true about CLUES, but not about what @SP mentioned which is placing the actual word into the grid. It’s entirely the constructor’s choice to include the word in the grid. The editors only modify clues. So I do agree with you that they can manipulate clues to that end.

@Paul

Hiw do you figure that? These puzzles are usually made by non-NYT creators. So you think they all are getting a kickback?

@Elizabeth Connors the creators get paid what they get paid and the NYT gets the supplemental revenue from how the manipulate or position the puzzle.   You think back in the day before the internet that the NYT ad sales folks didn’t call the advertisers when there was a related article in the food section?  You think there wasn’t a discussion with the movie studios when a big movie was about to come out about related content in the newspaper?   You’d be sadly let down to know that the person who runs the newspaper isn’t the editor in chief….its the managing editor who decides where the ads go and how many inches the writers get.  It’s about the money and has ALWAYS been about the money.

@Al  in Pittsburgh I have no idea why you think a newspaper trying to make revenue on all of their pages has anything to do with a conspiracy.  It’s naïveté to think that the NYT isn’t receptive to additional revenue from the puzzle pages no matter where it comes from.

The fact that you’re unwilling to see that is a you problem.

To address the topic of "conspiracy" to have advertised products in the puzzle.  No conspiracyjust business.

All newspapers are on the verge of going out of business...not just the New York Times.   Subscribers are dying off...and content is now locked behind a paywall.... In this conspiratorial AI world we live in...the subscriber base for the electronic versions is also shrinking...why pay for news when you can get something you cannot distinguish from real news on the feed on your phone?

All of that notwithstanding the NYT and its puzzle are in business to make money...and always has been.  The person who truly controls a newspaper is the managing editor since they set where the ads go vs the stories...AND help merge those two foci...AND always have.  When newspapers are rich it looks like the Editor in Chief sets the agenda...but that's always an illusion its always about the money.

Its why there is no longer a specialty puzzle or an acrostic included in the puzzle subscription.  Because that would mean paying the puzzle creators in perpetuity for their online use...Whereas a single run in print edition has a different pricing structure.

So when the question comes up....Which can be summarized as "Does the puzzle department care about increasing its revenue with an ever shrinking newspaper revenue world?"  Their is a singular answer....OF COURSE THEY DO.  Their careers depend on it.   So to think that there isnt paid content associated with puzzles is just folly.
